1.system_message:
Du bist ein Evaluator für medizinische Austrittsberichte einer Psychiatrie. Prüfe den Austrittsbericht auf fehlende medizinische Informationen and gib für jeden Abschnitt eine Ausgabe nach folgendem Schema:

Deine Ausgabe ist **ein reines JSON-Objekt*
* nach folgendem Schema:

* `"Abschnittsname": 1` wenn der Abschnitt medizinisch vollständig ist
* `"Abschnittsname": 0` wenn Informationen fehlen (z.B. Diagnosen, Befunde, Medikation) mit kurzer Begründung in einem Satz.

Gib das JSON-Objekt ohne Kommentare, Fließtext oder Einleitung zurück.

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear Dr. Anja Zwanghaft,

We are reporting on the above-mentioned patient, Mr. Eggli, who was under our care. After thorough examination and evaluation, we have diagnosed him with a severe recurrent depressive episode. In light of his depressed mood, lack of drive, feelings of emptiness, self-deprecating thoughts, guilt, sleep disturbances, and pessimistic future perspective, as well as historical indications of previous depressive episodes, this diagnosis seems most appropriate.

We have implemented a multimodal treatment program consisting of pharmacological intervention, psychotherapy (individual and group), and social support. For the pharmacological aspect, we started Venlafaxine at a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day and increased it to reach the target dose of 75 mg per day. During the dosage adjustment process, typical but tolerable side effects such as nausea, headache, dizziness, and increased sweating occurred; however, these resolved completely over time. Routine EKGs and lab tests were unremarkable throughout the treatment course.

In terms of psychotherapeutic themes, we found that Mr. Eggli often had negative thoughts about his professional performance, which led to feelings of worthlessness. During therapy sessions, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them. A coping strategy involved gathering concrete evidence of his abilities by recalling past successes or positive feedback from colleagues and supervisors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also employed to help him change his thought patterns and improve his self-esteem. Relaxation exercises and stress management techniques were taught to assist him in managing workplace challenges more effectively and enhancing his overall well-being.

Upon completion of the treatment, Mr. Eggli returned to his rental apartment and maintained his existing employment. In the follow-up period, there was significant improvement in thought content, drive, mood, and future perspective. At discharge, a largely remitted depressive syndrome without acute suicidal ideation was present. We are releasing Mr. Eggli in stable psychological condition with no signs of current or imminent self-harm or harm to others into his known living and working situations.

At discharge, the following medications were prescribed: Lisinopril 5 mg film tablet (Lisinopril), Venlafaxine 75 mg film tablet (Venlafaxine), and Dafalgan 500 mg tablet (Paracetamol).

For further ambulatory psychiatric care, we have arranged an appointment for Mr. Eggli with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 31st, 2024. His primary care will continue to be provided by Dr. med. Grundversorgung.

We recommend long-term abstinence from alcohol. Upon stabilization in the outpatient setting, we suggest a tapering off of Venlafaxine at the earliest after approximately 12-24 months; if there is any worsening of his condition, it may be necessary to reinitiate the dosage. We recommend continuation of the psychotherapeutic treatment, and Mr. Eggli wishes to discuss this further with Dr. Zwanghaft.

Should you have any questions or need further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact us. This document has been electronically reviewed and is valid even without a signature.

Best regards,

[Your Name]
[Your Position]

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear Dr. Anja Zwanghaft,

We are reporting on the above-mentioned patient, Mr. Eggli, who was under our stationary treatment from 01.03.2024 to 29.03.2024 and then under outpatient care until his discharge on 14.05.2024.

Diagnosis:
We diagnosed Mr. Eggli with a severe, recurrent depressive episode based on depressive mood, decreased drive, feelings of worthlessness, guilt, sleep disturbances, and pessimistic future perspectives, as well as biographical hints towards previous depressive episodes. We also considered an uncertain avoidant personality structure, but did not diagnose a personality disorder due to the currently strongly pronounced affective symptoms. No specific organic causes were found, particularly with an unremarkable MRI scan.

Treatment and Course:
During his hospital stay, Mr. Eggli participated in our multimodal treatment program, which included pharmacological treatment, psychotherapeutic individual and group therapy, as well as care coordination.

Pharmacologically, we decided to start Venlafaxine at a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day, to be gradually increased up to a target dose of 75 mg per day. During the titration process, typical but tolerable side effects such as nausea, headache, dizziness, and excessive sweating occurred, which resolved completely over time. Routine ECGs and laboratory tests were unremarkable throughout.

In psychotherapeutic sessions, it was found that Mr. Eggli often had negative thoughts about his work performance, leading to feelings of worthlessness. In therapy, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them. A coping strategy involved recording past successes or reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues or superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also used to change thought patterns and strengthen self-esteem. Relaxation exercises and stress management techniques were also provided to help him cope better with work challenges and improve his well-being.

Upon discharge, Mr. Eggli returned to his rental apartment and continued his employment.

Outcome:
The condition improved significantly during the hospital stay.

Medication at Discharge:
Lisinopril 5 mg film-coated tablet (Lisinopril)
Venlafaxine 75 mg film-coated tablet (Venlafaxine)
Paracetamol 500 mg tablet (Paracetamol)

Procedure:
1.0 tablet per day, in reserve; 1.0 tablet maximum per 24 hours: max. 3 tablets per day

Follow-up:
For Mr. Eggli's outpatient psychiatric follow-up, we have scheduled an appointment with Dr. Zwanghaft on 31.6.2024. His primary care will continue to be provided by Dr. med. Grundversorgung.

We recommend lifelong abstinence from alcohol.

After stabilization in the outpatient setting, we suggest a gradual tapering of Venlafaxine at least 12-24 months later, unless there is a worsening of symptoms, in which case a further increase in dosage would be considered. We also recommend continued outpatient psychotherapeutic treatment, which Mr. Eggli wishes to discuss with Dr. Zwanghaft.

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions. This document has been electronically viewed and is valid without signature.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
Copy to: Dr. Anja Zwanghaft

Dear [Patient's Name],

We, the healthcare team involved in your care during your recent hospitalization at our institution, are writing to provide you with a detailed report of your diagnosis and treatment. Upon presentation to our facility, we conducted a thorough medical and psychiatric evaluation which led us to diagnose you with a severe episode of depression. This was accompanied by symptoms such as low mood, anhedonia, decreased motivation, guilt, poor concentration, sleep disturbances, and thoughts of worthlessness. We also noted signs of physical agitation, restlessness, and psychomotor retardation during your assessment.

Your medical history includes a long-standing diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), for which you have been prescribed lisdexamfetamine. In addition, you have a history of migraine headaches that are controlled with propranolol and triptans. You also have a recent history of alcohol misuse, with occasional binge drinking episodes. Your medication regimen at the time of hospitalization included venlafaxine (75 mg), risperidone (2-4 mg), and lithium carbonate (900 mg).

You reported a significant history of stressors related to personal life events, including bereavement and financial difficulties. Your occupation as a construction worker is physically demanding, and you have reported work-related stressors. You have also experienced social isolation due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Psychological evaluation revealed that you struggled with feelings of worthlessness and excessive self-criticism. We noted symptoms of avoidance behavior and negative thought patterns, which contributed to your depression.

In our treatment plan, we initially prescribed a low dose of venlafaxine (37.5 mg) for you to start on. This medication was gradually increased over time as tolerated, up to the target dosage of 75 mg. We also recommended psychotherapy sessions, both in individual and group settings, which focused on cognitive behavioral techniques aimed at identifying negative thought patterns and challenging them. In addition, we provided relaxation exercises and stress management strategies.

During your hospitalization, we noted that you experienced side effects from venlafaxine, including nausea, headache, dizziness, and increased sweating, all of which subsided over time. We closely monitored your lab results and electrocardiograms to ensure the medication was not adversely affecting any other underlying medical conditions.

In terms of future treatment recommendations, we suggest that you continue with psychotherapy sessions to further address your negative thought patterns and coping strategies. Additionally, we advise that a follow-up appointment with your primary care physician is arranged for a routine health check-up. We also recommend a review of your medication regimen in around 12 months' time, particularly in relation to venlafaxine, provided there are no signs of relapse or further deterioration in symptoms.

In terms of your overall prognosis, we believe that with ongoing support and adherence to treatment, you will continue to experience improvements in your mood and mental wellbeing. We encourage you to remain in touch with us and your primary care physician if you encounter any concerns or setbacks in the future. If you have any questions regarding this report, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Sincerely,

Dear Dr. Zwanghaft,

I am pleased to provide you with the discharge summary of your patient, Mr. Eggli, who completed a stay at our facility for depression treatment. Below is a detailed account of his diagnosis, treatment plan, progress during the hospitalization, and recommendations for follow-up care.

Diagnosis: After careful evaluation, we have diagnosed Mr. Eggli with Major Depressive Disorder (recurrent). We also considered an unsure avoidant personality structure; however, given the current severe affective symptoms, we did not make a definitive diagnosis of a personality disorder. There were no indications of a specific organic etiology, particularly with an unremarkable MRI and EEG.

Treatment Plan: During his hospital stay, Mr. Eggli participated in our multimodal treatment program that included medical, pharmacological, psychotherapeutic, and social interventions. The pharmacologic approach involved starting Venlafaxine at a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day and gradually titrating it up to the target dose of 75 mg per day. Side effects during dosage adjustment were minimal but tolerable, such as mild nausea, headache, dizziness, and increased sweating, which all resolved over time. Venlafaxine and Lisinopril (5 mg film-coated tablets) will be continued at discharge, along with Dafalgan 500mg for pain management as needed.

Psychotherapeutic Interventions: In therapy sessions, we worked on identifying negative thoughts about his professional performance that led to feelings of worthlessness. We helped him develop a strategy for collecting evidence of his abilities and reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues or superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also employed to change his thought patterns and improve self-worth. Relaxation exercises and stress management strategies were taught to help him better cope with work challenges and enhance his wellbeing.

Social Situation: Upon discharge, Mr. Eggli returned to his rental apartment and continued his existing employment relationships.

Clinical Course: During his stay, we observed significant improvement in his cognitive processing, motivation, mood, and future perspective. At discharge, he presented with a largely remitted depressive syndrome without any signs of acute suicidal ideation. We are releasing Mr. Eggli in stable psychological condition, with no indications of imminent self- or external harm risks.

Follow-up Care: We arranged for an outpatient appointment with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 30, 2024, for continued psychiatric care. We recommend that his primary care physician continue to manage his health concerns.

We encourage Mr. Eggli to maintain abstinence from alcohol and suggest a gradual tapering of Venlafaxine after approximately 12-24 months if he remains stable. If he experiences worsening symptoms, we recommend considering additional dosage adjustments. We also suggest ongoing psychotherapeutic care, which Mr. Eggli should discuss with Dr. Zwanghaft.

Please do not hesitate to contact us for any follow-up questions or concerns. We wish Mr. Eggli continued success in his recovery process.

Best regards,
